key_0.snippet: In a surprising break with its march toward states' rights, the Supreme Court ruled today that states can be sued for violating their employees' federally guaranteed right to take time off for family emergencies.    The vote to reject Nevada's cla...
key_0.lead_paragraph: In a surprising break with its march toward states' rights, the Supreme Court ruled today that states can be sued for violating their employees' federally guaranteed right to take time off for family emergencies. The vote to reject Nevada's claim to constitutional immunity from suit under the Family and Medical Leave Act was a decisive 6 to 3. Most unexpectedly, the author of the majority opinion was Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, under whose leadership the court has produced a series of bitterly contested 5-to-4 decisions expanding the scope of the states' immunity from suit and, correspondingly, curbing the power of Congress to make federal law fully binding.
key_0.abstract: Supreme Court, in surprising break with its march toward states' rights, rules 6-3 that states can be sued for violating employees' federally guaranteed right to take time off for family emergencies; Chief Justice William Rehnquist is unexpected author of majority ruling rejecting Nevada's claim of constitutional immunity from suit under Family and Medical Leave Act; majority finds federal law narrowly targeted to address persistent, well-documented workplace problem of gender-based discrimination which assumes that caring for family is women's work; suit was brought by male employee, William Hibbs, who was dismissed after taking time off to care for ailing wife; photo (M)

headline.main: JUSTICES, 6-3, RULE WORKERS CAN SUE STATES OVER LEAVE

key_1.snippet: The United States Commission on Civil Rights today directed its staff to rework a report that recommended a one-year suspension of Federal programs that reserve contracts for black, Hispanic or female employers.   The panel did not specify what ch...
key_1.lead_paragraph: The United States Commission on Civil Rights today directed its staff to rework a report that recommended a one-year suspension of Federal programs that reserve contracts for black, Hispanic or female employers. The panel did not specify what changes should be made. Several commissioners said the panel should propose some ''positive alternatives'' if it wanted to halt the set-aside programs, under which businesses owned by women and members of minority groups receive more than $5 billion a year in Government contracts. Five of the eight commissioners expressed dissatisfaction with the draft report. The chairman of the commission, Clarence M. Pendleton Jr., strongly supported it.

headline.main: RIGHTS STAFF TOLD TO REWORK MINORITY BUSINESS REPORT

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

key_1.snippet: The Center for Individual Rights, a nonprofit conservative law firm, is fast developing an unusual niche: challenging colleges and universities on behalf of those who regard themselves as victims of political correctness.   The center, founded in ...
key_1.lead_paragraph: The Center for Individual Rights, a nonprofit conservative law firm, is fast developing an unusual niche: challenging colleges and universities on behalf of those who regard themselves as victims of political correctness. The center, founded in 1989, has gained prominence by winning high-profile cases like Ronald Rosenberger's against the University of Virginia. In a 5-to-4 decision in June, the Supreme Court held that the university was required to provide student-activity financing for a student-run religious magazine.

headline.main: Law Center Wages a Fight Against Political Correctness

key_1.snippet: A new report from the United States Commission on Civil Rights unequivocally rejects the proposition that men and women should be paid the same for different jobs of comparable worth.    The 232-page study concluded that ''comparable worth, as a t...
key_1.lead_paragraph: A new report from the United States Commission on Civil Rights unequivocally rejects the proposition that men and women should be paid the same for different jobs of comparable worth. The 232-page study concluded that ''comparable worth, as a theory of discrimination or as a remedy for discrimination, is profoundly and irretrievably flawed.'' Under a policy of comparable worth, employers assess the intrinsic value of different jobs by measuring such factors as the knowledge, skills and effort required of employees, their degree of responsibility and their working conditions.

headline.main: IDEA OF JOB WORTH IS CALLED 'FLAWED'

key_1.snippet: A major Federal program to reserve contracts for businesses owned by members of minority groups and women in the Northeast has been highly effective, according to a regional advisory panel of the United States Commission on Civil Rights.   The stu...
key_1.lead_paragraph: A major Federal program to reserve contracts for businesses owned by members of minority groups and women in the Northeast has been highly effective, according to a regional advisory panel of the United States Commission on Civil Rights. The study contradicts a report drafted by the staff of the commission, which said such programs were ineffective. The new study focused on a $2.2 billion project to improve the main Amtrak rail line running through eight states in the Northeast Corridor, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Because of 10 years of strong commitment from top officials at Amtrak and the Federal Transportation Department, the study said, this project surpassed its goal of awarding 15 percent of all contracts to businesses owned by blacks, Hispanic people and women. The actual volume of such awards was 17.8 percent, it said.

headline.main: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION EFFORT ON AMTRAK CORRIDOR PRAISED AS EFFECTIVE

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

key_1.snippet: After impassioned debate, the United States Commission on Civil Rights today urged Congress and Government agencies to reject the doctrine that men and women should be paid the same for different jobs of comparable worth.     The vote was 5 to 2. ...
key_1.lead_paragraph: After impassioned debate, the United States Commission on Civil Rights today urged Congress and Government agencies to reject the doctrine that men and women should be paid the same for different jobs of comparable worth. The vote was 5 to 2. One member, Francis S. Guess, the Tennessee State Commissioner of Labor, abstained. Voting with the majority, Morris B. Abram, vice chairman of the commission, said: ''There is sex-based discrimination in America, but it is declining. The repetitious charge that women earn only 60 percent of what men earn in this country obscures the significant fact that women work less hours, have less seniority and work more intermittently.''

headline.main: U. S. PANEL ON CIVIL RIGHTS REJECTS PAY-EQUITY THEORY

key_5.snippet: The United States Commission on Civil Rights today directed its staff to rework a report that recommended a one-year suspension of Federal programs that reserve contracts for black, Hispanic or female employers.   The panel did not specify what ch...
key_5.lead_paragraph: The United States Commission on Civil Rights today directed its staff to rework a report that recommended a one-year suspension of Federal programs that reserve contracts for black, Hispanic or female employers. The panel did not specify what changes should be made. Several commissioners said the panel should propose some ''positive alternatives'' if it wanted to halt the set-aside programs, under which businesses owned by women and members of minority groups receive more than $5 billion a year in Government contracts. Five of the eight commissioners expressed dissatisfaction with the draft report. The chairman of the commission, Clarence M. Pendleton Jr., strongly supported it.

headline.main: RIGHTS STAFF TOLD TO REWORK MINORITY BUSINESS REPORT

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

key_5.snippet: The Center for Individual Rights, a nonprofit conservative law firm, is fast developing an unusual niche: challenging colleges and universities on behalf of those who regard themselves as victims of political correctness.   The center, founded in ...
key_5.lead_paragraph: The Center for Individual Rights, a nonprofit conservative law firm, is fast developing an unusual niche: challenging colleges and universities on behalf of those who regard themselves as victims of political correctness. The center, founded in 1989, has gained prominence by winning high-profile cases like Ronald Rosenberger's against the University of Virginia. In a 5-to-4 decision in June, the Supreme Court held that the university was required to provide student-activity financing for a student-run religious magazine.

headline.main: Law Center Wages a Fight Against Political Correctness

key_5.snippet: A new report from the United States Commission on Civil Rights unequivocally rejects the proposition that men and women should be paid the same for different jobs of comparable worth.    The 232-page study concluded that ''comparable worth, as a t...
key_5.lead_paragraph: A new report from the United States Commission on Civil Rights unequivocally rejects the proposition that men and women should be paid the same for different jobs of comparable worth. The 232-page study concluded that ''comparable worth, as a theory of discrimination or as a remedy for discrimination, is profoundly and irretrievably flawed.'' Under a policy of comparable worth, employers assess the intrinsic value of different jobs by measuring such factors as the knowledge, skills and effort required of employees, their degree of responsibility and their working conditions.

headline.main: IDEA OF JOB WORTH IS CALLED 'FLAWED'

key_5.snippet: A major Federal program to reserve contracts for businesses owned by members of minority groups and women in the Northeast has been highly effective, according to a regional advisory panel of the United States Commission on Civil Rights.   The stu...
key_5.lead_paragraph: A major Federal program to reserve contracts for businesses owned by members of minority groups and women in the Northeast has been highly effective, according to a regional advisory panel of the United States Commission on Civil Rights. The study contradicts a report drafted by the staff of the commission, which said such programs were ineffective. The new study focused on a $2.2 billion project to improve the main Amtrak rail line running through eight states in the Northeast Corridor, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Because of 10 years of strong commitment from top officials at Amtrak and the Federal Transportation Department, the study said, this project surpassed its goal of awarding 15 percent of all contracts to businesses owned by blacks, Hispanic people and women. The actual volume of such awards was 17.8 percent, it said.

headline.main: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION EFFORT ON AMTRAK CORRIDOR PRAISED AS EFFECTIVE

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

key_5.snippet: After impassioned debate, the United States Commission on Civil Rights today urged Congress and Government agencies to reject the doctrine that men and women should be paid the same for different jobs of comparable worth.     The vote was 5 to 2. ...
key_5.lead_paragraph: After impassioned debate, the United States Commission on Civil Rights today urged Congress and Government agencies to reject the doctrine that men and women should be paid the same for different jobs of comparable worth. The vote was 5 to 2. One member, Francis S. Guess, the Tennessee State Commissioner of Labor, abstained. Voting with the majority, Morris B. Abram, vice chairman of the commission, said: ''There is sex-based discrimination in America, but it is declining. The repetitious charge that women earn only 60 percent of what men earn in this country obscures the significant fact that women work less hours, have less seniority and work more intermittently.''

headline.main: U. S. PANEL ON CIVIL RIGHTS REJECTS PAY-EQUITY THEORY

key_9.snippet: Following a ruling by a state agency that Princeton University's three all-male eating clubs unlawfully discriminate against women, those involved in the case are preparing for a lengthy legal battle and assessing the decision's implications.   Th...
key_9.lead_paragraph: Following a ruling by a state agency that Princeton University's three all-male eating clubs unlawfully discriminate against women, those involved in the case are preparing for a lengthy legal battle and assessing the decision's implications. The New Jersey Division of Civil Rights ruled this week that the clubs' ties to the university render them public accommodations and therefore subject to the same law concerning discrimination as the university. The decision came in a five-year-old complaint by Sally Frank, a 1980 Princeton graduate whose requests to join the eating clubs were rejected in 1979. The decision, which established state jurisdiction over the clubs, is not binding, but will probably result in an order by the division for the clubs to consider women for admission, according to the participants. Such an order could be appealed to the courts, however.

headline.main: COURT FIGHT SEEN ON PRINCETON CLUBS
